Friday Eve 1/2 past 10 o'clock  Boston Sept 12th 1856
Dear Sister Abby
I have just returned from 
one of the most crowded meetings I ever attended.
A large & crowded political gathering in the Tremont 
Temple on the occasion of the reception of Anson 
Burlingame on his return from Washington ---- 
I think I never saw such a tremendous turnout 
of ladies & Gentlemen --- The large halls in the 
Tremont Temple were all crowded to the utmost & 
Tremont St for a long distance each way from 
the temple was also densely crowded there being no 
room in side for any more. I cannot begin to 
tell a hundreth part of the great excitement in and 
arround the Temple --- I made my way in to the 
large hall in the temple & after hearing Burlingame 
H. Wilson & others I made my way out half melted 
& roasted -- & in a jambed up condition -- After getting 
to the street I could go no further for the crowd 
was immense & impenetrable -- I however pressed gradually 
through in course of an hour during which time Burlingame
D7
[written sideways] Be sure & give lots of love to my good mother & Chandler

and others appeared at one of the front windows 
of the Temple & addressed the crowding & crazy crowd. 
Such cheering, such tossing of hats waving of hands 
& throwing of boquets I never saw as in the temple to
night — O it was a general rush & no mistake — 
Every Fremont Club anywhere near Boston was 
there with banners, mottoes music etc. — 
Well I got out of the crowd at last and home I came 
finding it rather late  — the Old South struck 10 before 
I got home — But I cannot go to bed till I have said a 
few words and they must be brief — I was very happy 
to receive a letter from you Abby — Your letters do 
me much good & you must write often — do Abby and 
I shall ever try to answer them — I do not wonder that 
you are more lonely now Mary has gone, but you 
must look around you & call on your friends & have 
good times, write to Mary often & to me, take occasionally 
a pleasant walk think of me think of your many 
friends, enjoy what we have enjoyed together the 
scenes around our old home — You have Mother and 
Chandler & err this perhaps other kind friends to cheer 
your pathway by their or his presence — Yes Abby 
I have felt lonely often — I know how you must feel & 
I wish I might often see you and talk all about this —

Monday morning I read a letter from Mary — 
she is well and writes in her usual style — 
I rec'd also a letter from Concord Monday — 
A very good letter too — I think I would like 
to call up then & see the folks — They have 
not heard from you & are expecting a letter. 
You know Charlotte little boy is dead — 
Fanny has been sick — is better now — I gave 
your letter to Fred and told him to send it to Agnes — 
I should like to have carried it myself but 
thought perhaps twas not best — I have not seen 
her for a long long while & when we may meet 
again is uncertain — is it not rather strange — 
perhaps I may call over soon — I don't know 
hardly what to do — I always thought A. 
friendly and cannot think otherwise now — 
I hope we may be friends I am sure always — 
I saw Lorin and Jonathan Igler yesterday or no 
it was tuesday eve — Lorin made me read your 
and Mary's letters (of course I did not read quite all) he 
said they were very good letters indeed & I think so — 
I saw David Igler today & D. Randall — all well well — all well at Johns 
& Sumners I believe — I must bid you goodnight affecly Charles
[written on the left-hand side of the page]
Chandler I put in a little slip of paper for you to keep till
I see you - Chandler why did you not say a few words - do write

Samuel & Maria
Dear Br & Sister
You & Alma are not 
forgotten. I think of you often — I think of your 
pleasant home & the pleasant hours I have passed there. 
I remember your smiles & your kindness —I remember 
how sad you looked too the last time I saw you at 
your home & little Alma was sick— I hope you are 
having grand good times this summer—I don't know 
but you think I forgot you , tis not so & I hope to 
be fondly remembered by you —I would say more but tis 
very late & I must go to the P.O. or it will not go to W—
by tomorrows mail — accept these few words written al-
most in the dark with my best wishes  — good night. 
Good night little Alma
Charles

Chandler my last letter to you was very short 
I had to be very brief then for it was late & I was not at home. 
But more next time.
Great times here now & greater next week—
Good night once more to all
C

Boston Oct 13, 1856
Dear Sister Abby
I recd yours 
of the 7th ?? also one enclosed from 
my old Cul...a friends -- I thank you 
very much for your kindness in writing. 
And say to Chandler 'thank you Sir' (for me) 
and tell him all is right in regard to what 
he alludes - I will answer the western letter 
soon and tell a fair story as possible --
I am well as usual - felt quite smart -- 
have been generally well -- I have staid lon-
ger than I expected where I am - don't expect 
to remain there this winter - shall know 
soon though - Mr. W is going to New York 
in a few days to make a short stay - If 
good big pay is in prospection of course I 
might stay - Business is getting still --
I think I cannot fail to jump into 
something profitable by another spring - 
I went to hear The Parke yesterday AM. 
went to Somerville & took Dinner with Mr 
Wilder yesterday - took tea at cousin Mary's
All well - & all right for Zi no- I think

(Remember me to Mary David 
goes out to ride on the old white nag 
without a veil on, and a spur or a Bean who [[h--] )
Cousin Mary's a watchful Mama. 
But I must say I regard her as a good 
woman & true friend especially to those 
she loves. She is a very shrewd woman 
and I feel kinder lookout-a-fied but I am 
taking up and laying down my boots 
kinder softly & slowly - A is your friend & 
mine I think further than this my pen 
don't say -- I am treated kindly of 
course & wish to be considered friendly. 
I have a very good opinion of  -- 
you know but mum is the word. 
I say but little -- this letter is con-
fidential & you need not expose any 
of the hints -- I feel like talking to 
a sister -- use caution -- when you write 
feel free with her as ever for you know 
all that I do -- nothing new -- but be 
judicious in speaking of me that no 
wrong suppositions be entertained -- 
I admire prudence though I am a complete 
blunderhead myself -- O Abby I guess we 
would have one of the nicest little 
"talkovers" (as many calls it) ever known

& tell her she can take my hat when 
g[ ] & tell her not to go beyond the meeting house
[…] has a knowledge of the country.
I told A that you thought she was 
not going to write & she said she had 
written. We don’t communicate except 
verbally now. I am considered true & 
friendly & so I do really feel I cannot 
feel otherwise so long as I am well treated. 
I don’t know anybodies ideas but my 
own & then their ideas Charles keeps hid. 
But be ever friendly and kind in your 
words to ------ You know time 
tells all things & I am very patient. 
I shall be somewhat anxious to see 
the western----. type - O I guess youll 
find – O. I guess, O. O. I guess you’ll find. 
Well all right I aint going to player you till 
I come up and I think that may be in 
November – if I come this season. 
Will try and be up Thanksgiving – 
Yet it may be I shall not. 
Give my love to all & I don’t know 
how you’ll manage not to let [illegible] 
see this yet I don’t want only such 
and which ones to get at the drift of this. 
I guess you need not expose any of it. 
Keep cool & courteous. Good by Charles.

Boston Dec 8th 1856
Dear Sister
If you know how anxious I am to 
hear from you I think a letter would be here tomorrow. 
I shall certainly expect a good long letter from some of 
you tomorrow. Why dont you write? I hope you dont 
think I do not wish to hear from home because I come 
not to see you. I did not willingly absent myself 
from home Thanksgiving, but it seemed almost necessary 
for me to do so. The hope of remaining in business all 
or a part of the winter, induced me to make the great 
sacrifice & thus I have denied myself; & have not seen 
you & am still in the city. I am here; I passed here the 
day of general family gathering. But Thanksgiving did 
not pass without many a thought for you all. I not only thought 
of you but I sighed for your presence & my greatest pleasure 
during the day was that derived from meditating upon 
home & home scenes. I doubt not you had a pleasant and 
spicy time, all filled with delight, yet I am not going to say 
(that I think) you had as good a time as though the circle (was) had been complete. 
Twas my fault that circle was broken; yet deem it not a 
fault, for I felt that in leaving at that time, I might 
deprive myself of what then appeared to me, a favorable op-
portunity to do a little something this winter for the poor Boy. 
For the loss I sustained in not meeting you, I am only paid 
in the hope of yet meeting you ere long and then to have a 
Thanksgiving. Can we not make such a meeting a day of thanksgiving.

How did you passe the day? Did you all have a 
great time. Who was there. Was Every body there 
but me. I could ask a thousand questions but 
tis not necessary. You can tell me all about it. 
I staid at my boarding place all day. 
We had a comfortable dinner & the day passed 
of tolerably quiet. In the Eve I went to the Boston Theater 
& enjoyed it very much. Having once bid all 
the Cousins good by with the intention of going home. 
I thought I would not surprise them by popping 
in to get a thanksgiving bite, though I have no doubt 
they would have been awful glad to see me. 
I am getting more & more inclined to hermit it out among 
strangers. I cannot tell the reason, but I dont travel much 
out of the city. I am very busy of late and find no time to 
go any where. I saw Ias Jones today. It is more confining 
where I am now. But I am doing better than in the 
Summer. I may not long continue where I am 
and yet I may pass the winter. If on the return of my 
employer from the east (Down East) we can make any per-
manent bargain we will do so. If I do not I will come 
and see you. Write to me often.
Good night Abby giv my love to all
Yours Affectionately
Chas Reed
Mary & Mother I send you my love & hope you 
will excuse me in not writing more at this time. 
Please remember me. good night. write to me Mary. 
Giv my love to all our folks. truly Charles

Boston Jan 15th 1857
Dear Sister Abby
Your letter dated 
the 11th unclear came to hand yesterday P.M. 
I must say that I have not rec'd a letter 
for a long while that seemed to be more 
interesting candid and truthful. You will 
please accept my thanks for that good 
long letter. Of late I have written only short 
and hasty letters of which your "wee letter" 
which you recd last week was a specimen. 
I have been looking for a letter from 
you for some time but I do not complain 
since such a good one has come at last. 
You allude with some degree of seriousness 
to an important and interesting event, which 
is to take place sometime next Spring. 
You may have had reason to suppose from 
my remarks in the little note I sent you 
that I was disposed to treat this matter 
too lightly or with playful indifference. 
But could you have seen these Eyes moist-
en as I perused the words, from your own 
pen, assuring me of the certainty of 
Your prospect of leaving us. You would
[written on the left-hand side of the page]
I shall send your note to A or carry it soon. I have not seen her for 
2 months. Everything friendly I suppose but then you know. You know. 
Love & Friendship is two aint it 
I have no Lady friend 
I think more of than 
my sisters
D10

begin to think that your Brother Charles 
is not quite so easily reconciled to parting 
with one who has ever been a true [hurted?] kind 
and affectionate Sister. Notwithstanding 
I have received communications indicating 
that an engagement might exist and event-
ually Marriage would ensure in course of time, Yet 
I never till now have considered such things 
as a settled fact. Now then dear sister I 
thank you for revealing to me yourself what 
has long been to you a secret at least may I not 
say a cherished hope. And since your own 
judgment has decided the future course of action 
relative to the most important step in life I shall 
most heartily coincide with you and approve 
of your choice relying wholly on your taste 
for preference. I therefore do not take 
my pen to startle you with objections. 
In reality, having never seen Mr. Kendall I can 
not raise the slightest objection, on the courting 
I have heard much of him that is commendable & praise-
worthy. I have only to say that I believe 
you to be worthy of a true man of Excellence; or 
as I might have said, a Man of true Excellence & 
I know you deem your chosen companion 
as worthy that title. In parting , then, with

those whom you have known as near & dear 
friends you go with your dearest friend. 
And if the hour of parting must come 
the grief will be greatly modified if not dispelled 
by the assurance of the loved one's happiness 
being entrusted to so good & worthy a person 
as Mr Kendall. You need have no fears 
about my not liking one whom you can love 
better than a brother and with whom you 
can willingly follow to a distant land, leaving 
mother Sisters Brothers and all dear as-
sosiations of Home behind. A regards 
going west, people are going; have gone 
and will go. It is reasonable or I would 
say natural for us who are to be deprived 
of your presence to object or reluctantly give 
consent to your going so far to permanently 
reside. Yet Once arrived in the western country
I doubt not you would like as well  as any-
where out of Old Warwick. It will be hard 
to be reconciled to this distance. Yet 2 or 3 
days will be sufficient to travel over the road. 
I am 3 hours ride from home but tis nearly 
a year since I have seen you all. If I was 
in Illinois I could at least see you as often. 
Abby with all the fullness of an honest heart 
I wish you happiness and prosperity and in 
this coming change may it be for your mutual happiness
Love to all & Remember me to Mr. K. Truly Charles.

Jan 21st

If I was with you I could talk all about things

Boston March 13th 1857
Dear Sister Abby
I will say a few words
to you and hope you will excuse my
not writing a long letter this time for I
wish to go to a meeting tonight at the
Tremont Temple - I was very glad to hear
from  you and your letter was certainly a good
one and such as one as I would like to often
receive - It seems to me that there is more mind
and soul in your letters of late than formerly and 
you always wrote very good letters - Perhaps the
thought of leaving your friends this Spring
may have occasioned serious thought and thus
your expressions speak of thought & reflections
But undoubtedly you will triumph over grief
at parting for you are then nearer to your Dearest
friend while leaving other dear friends behind -
I see no reason then why to you Dear Sister the future
may not seem unclouded & brilliant with the never
fading light of a Star in the West Good may that
star exist to light your pathway with a radiant glow
of sunny smiles and with a reflection from your own
bright eye may each returning smile give luster to his own.
To have & to know we have a true friend whose constant and
undeviating affection tells with truth love is reciprocated 
and therefore natural, is one of the highest order of Satisfactions

You speak of your approaching wedding day.
May it come and find you & yours prepared to enjoy
and event so full of interest & delight - We are or should
be happy to see Our friends happy 0 As one who claims
to be a near & dear friend I would most willingly
bend my steps towards the scene of Bridal feasting
where smiles of gladness and tears begin & burst
from friendly Eyes all around - I have seen one
Dear sister led to the altar & have seen her many a
time since happy as when hand in hand the Bride
stood beside her chosen one in the presence of all our
family - Years have passed and one then with us is
no more. Yet the surviving links of that family circle will
as joyfully gather in the Old Parlor to see once more
a Similar Scene when it seems to hard to say it, you
alone will be changed, changed no; only in name.
Then as You are the next to call us together to rejoice
with you and Share your Sorrow (for a wedding day
has some sorrow if ever so pleasant) may it be no less
a happy day than was Our Dear Sis Emily's -
Of other weddings in Our family I can not speak
having by wandering foolishness or foolishly wander-
ing kept out of the way when they came off -
I sometimes feel that I shall be to busy to go
to my own wedding & therefor it is doubtful
whether I go to more than two or 3 more weddings in 
Our family so I guess you might as well cal-
culate on cake enough to let me have a piece for I must
try and come to Our Gal's Party -

I am quite well and remain as
usual in business matters -
I saw Agnes 2 weeks ago - saw Ias Goldsburg -
have not seen Spooner - no news in paricular.
I must close with saying may all truly and
pleasantly come to pass that tends to your happiness
Give my love to all
[Illegible] Your Brother
Affec'y
Charles Reed

Boston June 18th 1857
Dear Sister Abby
I have just rec'd your letter dated 13th
A glance at the hand writing and post mark gave me the pleas-
ing assurance that I held in my possession tiding from Abby.
The perusal of your friendly lines affected a happy change in my
feelings, and anxiety gave place to joy and satisfaction -
I feel very thankful to receive favorable news - Please accept my thanks
for thus early remembering me, and favoring me with a letter.
I am happy to learn that in due time I may have the pleasure of
reading a full account of your "Wedding Tour" - Having heard of your
safe arrival and comfortable state of health, I can wait more patiently
for additional news - I hope that when those "18 pages" have fulfilled
their happy mission at Warwick, and have cheered the hearts of
"loved ones at home," they will quickly resume their western flight and 
speedily continue till they safely rest in my hands and I assure
you they will be received with no less delight by reason of a short delay
at Maple Grove for inspection - "The few lines" you have been pleasant
to send direct to me, affords me much satisfaction, and they have pre-
pared my mind & heart to relish & enjoy the promised forthcoming letter.
I shall expect to see it next week and it will be hailed with a welcome equal
to my present longing for its arrival. Had news come that you
was, or had been, sick or that any cloud had o'ershadowed your pathway since
your departure for the west, a corresponding gloom would be cast over and
about me, and I should anticipate less pleasure in reading the account
of your journey - I am thankful that your "Tour" was a pleasant one -

Abby you are now quite a long distance from me and I can hardly
realize that you are in La Porte instead of Warwick - But thus it is and now
my thoughts while roaming come not back again till they have wandered
far westward beyond Maple Grove o'er mountains and plains o'er rivers & lakes
o'er cities & towns to the place you now call your home, in search of
my Sister Abby and another friend who I may now call a Brother -
In imagination I have oft before visited the same place in search of
that friend, then unknown to me but dear to me because dearest to you -
In reality we at last did meet - 'Twas our first, it may be our last meeting
but I shall not soon forget the pleasure enjoyed at that time - 
It may not be proper to make personal allusions - Suffice it to say that
I should be most happy to have further acquaintance and will hope
to have many a personal interview in the future believing I
could derive both pleasure and benefit in so doing -
The grief of parting with you Dear Sister and with him is cancelled
only in the belief that your mutual happiness depended on such
a result - Ultimately may it  know best - I hope it will for you & for him
We should have been most happy to have known that in the event
of your marriage you could still be near to us when often as hereupon
we could meet - Local attractions however should be modified
by due considerations - His interests are yours - Business has 
claims upon men which if this regarded renders success and prosperity
uncertain, saying nothing of health, which is of the greater importance.
Now then since you have really strayed away from us, I hesitate not
to say that you will never have occasion to regret so doing -
If I judge rightly your chances for happiness here and hereafter were
never more favorable - You will undoubtedly in your present im-
portant and honorable relationship, find not only the pleasures of

a happy home, but will soon enjoy the pleasures of kind friends and
associates, endearing and permanent, unrivaled even by the
happy reminiscences of New England save it be perhaps for a time
at least the pleasures of early home around our own family [illegible]
'Tis hard to forget an early home - We may meet the dearest of friends and
behold fairer scenes to view, but memory clings ever to the past -
Yes all these home pleasures can and will be remembered and enjoyed still.
Tis not expected and does not necessarily follow (so it seems to me) that
in the event of the Union of hearts, in order to fully enjoy the future
the past must be forgotten - Let the pleasures of the past min-
gle with the joys of the future - And may happy days to come be
happier by bringing up the memories of happy recollections -
May your future lives be as happy as the happiest of happy days can be -
May the important station you now fill inspire you with the
purest and noblest thoughts than can be cherished in a true
womans heart and may you continue ever in the ascen-
ding scale of usefulness and goodness - In regard to this
dear sister I have no fears and the happiest of thoughts are mine.
You have been a dear good sister, the same to me you will ever be -
We have enjoyed many happy days at the homestead - Childhood
lasts not forever - Happy too has been our meetings of later years.
Changes necessarily must occur - But of all the changes thus far
our number is still the same - We all live to enjoy still the hope
of meeting - Wherever you may be you are still dear to your
early friends, Mother, Brs & Sisters will not forget our Abby -
Feeling that the recent change is for your happiness & the happiness
of Your dearest Earthly friend, I cannot [mmur] at the loss of your
presence but hope often still to meet you. From Your Brother Charles Reed
with much love to you &  yours I close goodby

We did try to enjoy ourselves 
after you left – but every pleasure 
seemed to be dampened by your 
absence and particularly Singing.  
On Our arrival home from Winchester 
Monday AM, notwithstanding 
the parting scene had to some extent 
been all we could bear Yet, I say, a 
little something occurred after our arrival 
home that caused my eyes to fill to 
overflowing with the tears that had 
been welling up too long in a hidden 
fountain – 'Twas this, One by one at 
our leisure We gathered in the parlor – 
We looked at each other & said but little. 
I need not tell You where were our thoughts. 
Presently, Jane Stepped up the Melo-
deon. And commenced playing a tune 
You oft have played – all were silent

And Jane little thought that she 
was going to cause tears to flow – 
I looked at Mary – She was in tears – 
Twas too much for me – I, who had been 
brave through it all, had made You l
augh in the most serious past, and 
had hidden my grief, alas, the time 
had come and I could hold out no 
longer  – I left the room, sought a 
lone retreat and gave vent to my tears. 
Happily for me that I did so, for I was 
more sad than my feelings had man-
ifested, and this brought some relief – 
I soon after became cheerful, so did 
others and we did have tolerable good 
times – I went round but little– Spent 
my time with mother Br & Sisters. 
Although rainy when I started, it was 
pleasant when I arrived in the city. 
I am well – have been [since] I saw. I will write 
again soon – please write often
							Yours Truly, 
							Charles Reed
my best wishes to you & Mr Kendall

The 17th was lively but [tellevers?] and
I was glad when it was over - I staid in 
the office till 9 o'clock wrote to many &c
seen the procession - went over to Burke Hill's
and spent the Eve at home - retired early
Saw Dr. Beilz - Dr. Dillling [illegible] & Charley Stewart 
I shall speak next time about the matter
of Bookkeeping &c - have not time to write
more now - I am quite well - Write soon
as you can - Goodby C. R.

Boston July 21st 1857
Dear Sister Abby
How do you do?
And how is your husband Mr. Kendall? 
I hope you are quite well – I have not taken my 
pen to write a letter only to say a few words before 
I start for my boarding place. Tis most 7 oclock 
and I must take the coach at 4 – I am well – 
I recd and perused your 18 pages sometime ago and I 
intended to write long ago but have been very busy and 
Mr Wilder has been absent some of the time – Last week 
he went to Albany & was gone most of the week  – 
No day is so busy that You are forgotten  – and you 
will be constantly remembered whether I write or not – 
But I shall write as often as I can I shall be more at leisure 
soon  – Mary spent the 4th at  unclear also Uncle David. 
I recd a letter from her while there – Our folks are well last 
accounts  – Our friends are well here  – several of them have 
read Your long letter and were highly pleased and say 
you are quite a good hand to give a description. I took 
much pleasure in reading it  – I have been over the road and 
part of the way it seemed as though I was going over the same 
route as before  – Agnes recd your letter & let me read part of it. 
I will write soon  – I thought I would just say How de do  – 
in haste Yours affectionately
Much love to You and Bro Kendall – Good by for now. Charles Reed

Somerville Sept 13th 1857
Dear Sister Abby
I have another favorable opportunity
to send you a few lines.
Last Eve I had the pleasure of meeting
at the American House Boston, Mr. D.W. Kendall, wife, & Sister, and
as I sat conversing with them I could not help reverting to the event
upon which was based the priveledge of presenting myself as a
stranger to receive more than a strangers welcome. Your relation-
ship to one who has friendship for us all was my passport to
their presence and to show you the [victor] of that passport, let
me say that a card with your Brother's Name written there on gain-
ed for me an admittance and a smile of welcome from the trio
of new found friends. For the kind reception and attention
shown me during my stay, I am, first, indebted to their regard
for those I love and alike dear to them and secondly to their own
naturally friendly dispositions and inclinations toward
those they may deem worthy of their notice and attention.
I felt a hesitation in approaching those scarcely familiar with
even my name, but I could not forego the pleasure of hearing
your name breathed forth by those who I had reason to believe
could take some pleasure in so doing. At least when spoken
in connection with one ever so dear from childhoods days, to
then and now to speak his name is but to speak yours also -
And I must say that during our conversation which lasted about
an hour I had frequent evidence of the kind remembrance towards

would be very happy to have

Boston Aug 6th 1857
Dear Br Kendall
I wrote a few lines
to Sister Abby last week and should
not write again quite so soon, had I
not an Extra Change to send a letter
Mr. Rice of the firm of Rice Smith & Co
Plymouth Ind is in the city purchasing
goods for the Plymouth trade, is sending
his goods by the Merchant Western Line, and
has had occasion to call several times on
business at Our Office - One day I asked
him if he was acquainted in La Porte -
This was the "first of a Series" of questions which
followed on receiving an affirmative answer.
I must say that I was agreeably surprised
on learning that I was conversing with one
who not only had visited La Porte but who was
an acquaintance and a friend of yours -
The mere mention of his name therefore is a
sufficient introduction for (judging from our
conversation) he is well and favorably known to you
I had but a little time to converse with him for
he has been very busy during his stay, but I
must say that this accidental meeting has af-
forded me much pleasure and satisfaction -

I made myself known to him and he readily under-
stood the reason of this "Yankee's being fond of
asking questions" and seemed delighted in
being able to afford me pleasure by answering
a few questions - It seemed to me the next thing
to meeting you and since he has surprise
one he may as well the other on his return home -
He has expressed a willingness to be "bearer of Dispatches"
to a friend & I therefore prepare a few lines, hoping
they will reach you Early & be acceptable - Mr. Rice
told me that he had not had the pleasure of seeing
Mrs. Kendall - He may not say the same should
I meet him again, on the suppositions that your
friends are now her friends and a meeting may
be anticipated - Perhaps Mr. R will be favored
with an introduction when he delivers this message.
If I had opportunity I think I should enjoy
to hear Mr. R relate his Experience in the West -
Mr. R leaves for Plymouth to day - I like his
appearance and shall be happy to meet him again.
I hope his Goods will all get home safe as well as himself
I am well - Everything
continues about the same as when I last wrote.
I am Expecting a letter from Warwick every Day.
I should be very happy to hear from you often and
please favor me with a letter at your Earliest Convenience.
I will hold myself in readiness to answer all letters.
Please accept my thanks for your kind remembrance in Sister's

letter and bear in mind that I shall highly
appreciate your kind considerations and
continued remembrance - I shall feel a
deep interest in your welfare & happiness and
my best wishes attend you - I receive very
favorable letters from sister and am highly grat-
ified to learn that she is so contended and happy -
I may not see you & Abby often, but I have much
to remember that affords me pleasure - Abby has
been to me a Dear good sister and no changes
in life will make her memory less dear to me -
Hoping that you both may glide o'er lifes rug-
ged way pleasantly & happily together and your
whole life be one bright summer's day I again
say that ever shall the best wishes of my heart attend you
(With much love to you & Sister [illegible]
Yours Affectionately
Charles Reed

I am daily
expecting a letter from you
so if it is not already on the way

You have probably received
ere this a letter which I sent
to you by D Kendall.

continued good since I last
wrote and I am still at the same

Where I may be is at present uncer-
tain but I will write you often

you may direct letters the same as you

[written along the left-hand side]
I hope soon to hear that you and your husband are quite well and happy 
Remember me particularly
to Br. Kendall
and say
him I should
be very happy
to receive a few
lines from him
Good By

but shall act no longer for the same
parties as heretofore.
Mr. Wilder is now
in New York trying to effect an
arrangement with another party
and if he succeeds he will probably con-
tinue in the same business at this
office - I am now alone anxiously
awaiting his return. If he is successful
and secures the object of his present
visit to New York there may be a chance

I wish I could write more definitely

[written along the left-hand side]
Please remember me to Mr. and Mrs. David Kendall (and Miss K)

[written along the top of the page]
Mr. Wales of Stoughton [over?] here lately &

have plenty of time today to write

and I thought I would say a few

No 2 Broad St Boston Nov 19th 1857
Dear Sister Abby
Your letter dated Nov 1st
was received in due time. On the 9th
I commenced a letter but did not finish
it. I will now commence again and
say a few words and send it along with-
out further delay - I am still at No. 2 Broad St.
but shall remain but a few days longer -
I may stay till thanksgiving which ocmes
next week on Thursday (Nov 26) and shall
probably go to Chandlers wedding and then
go to Warwick and remain two or three weeks.
Chandler will be married Thanksgiving Eve -
'Tis also Thanksgiving at La Porte (Nov 26) the
same time that it is here - You can in thought
be with us - We shall think of you and oft will
your name be spoken - Tis sweet to know that
we are remembered - I would be pleased to 
meet you and Mr. Kendall in Warwick with
the rest of our friends but of course cannot expect to -

But I hope we may not be separated long
but enjoy many happy meetings.
Yes, a few days more & I expect to see my
mother, Mary, Chandler, and all Our folks
at Warwick - I shall miss you and in 
thought very often go to La Porte and inquire
for Sis Abby. We shall sit together where
often you have been one of the circle, where
we have laughed, talked, and sung together.
Occasionally I may look in to the parlor
where marched we in to presence of Rev.
John and others, after taking improper
steps (Hay & Straw foot strides) in tother room.
We shall oft be reminded of that friendly gathering
on the eve of your birthday. I have often
reviewed the whole that then transpired
and it has afforded me pleasure -
Chandler will not have any one to 
stand up with him - He wishes me
to be there and I shall try to be there.
I hope the day will be a pleasant one.
David Tyler & Lorin with their families

are expected to be there. Mary will
not be present - Perhaps I may invite
Cousin A to go with me to
Wattham but I don't know - I was in

time - She has a vacation next week -

to feel sad & mournful in Sumner talks

and everybody is bothered to death with hard
times. There is no money anywhere - I
have not received any for sometime but expect it soon -
I hope you are well - Direct your next to Warwick.
and till I write again Remember me to Mr. Kendall

"Maple Grove" Warwick February 19th 1858
Dear Sister Abby
I will try and write you a few
words - I am well. Mother and Mary are also well and
here we are in the sitting room. Mary is sewing at the
lightstand opposite me, and is looking thoughtfully happy -
Mother is near us, seemingly in a cheerful mood, and is look0
ing smart, but this cold weather makes us all feel rather [illegible]
and we have to keep a good fire to be comfortable -
Mother says some of us ought to write to Abby. She often says
so, and this evening I have taken my pen to comply with her
wishes and my own - I have been reading to Mary from
the Waverly since supper but have laid reading aside wishing
to write a few lines ere I retire so that I can send my tomorrow's mail.
Chandler & Rhoda have gone to make a call at Mr. Jones -
They are well - They desired Mary & I to accompany them but
we concluded to stay with mother. Wednesday eve however we four
went by invitation to Mr. Gilbert Stevens & spent the eve very pleasantly.
Joseph Green & wife were there also N. E. Stevens & wife. We had a pleasant
time. Twas very cold but good sleighing - We have had two weeks
of severe winter weather. Plenty of snow for good sleighing here
but little or now snow below at Athol - They are trying to get
up a Sleigh Ride - I don't know who will go - Our folks think we
had not better join the party an dprobably we should not -
I was over to Emilys & Samuels a little while Wednesday P.M. They 
are well. Their school closes or rather has closed today - I guess
from what I have heard that they have not had a very good school
[written on the left-hand side of the page]
I probably shall go somewhere soon & probably to Boston - No engagements yet - I have just heard from Concord
They are well there and all well in Boston & vicinity except little Sammy Belding at Mary's - I have not received any letter from
A. [Simon?] I came up, nor
from any of the cousins
except from Concord folks.
If you write to me, send to 
Warwick & if I am not here
they will forward to me -

Danford has manifest some dissatisfaction with the general
movement of the school afairs in that school. We did not go to
the examination - We all went in to our village school at the

worked in the woods some, but not regularly - Danford is cutting
those sapling pines at the left of the new road to Samuel Goldsburg's -
They are cutting them off very fast and Samuel has a two horse team
with which he draws this pine timber to the sawmill near to
Chandlers - Samuel agreed to draw one Hundred Cords - Samuel is very

village - Mr. Goldsburg folks are well - James Jr is not at home - He

& family are well - John G has been [illegible] all winter but is going

[written on the left-hand side of the page]
Chandler & Rhoda have just returned they send you their love & best wishes & also to Mr. Kendall

The agricultural Society is going ahead in good earnest - The Singing

Thursday Morn June 4th / 58
Dear Sister Abby
I will say a
few words and put in with Emily's & Mary's 
letters which have been sent up for me to mail -
You say your curiosity has been excited -
No wonder -
I know to whom you refer. I
may not however fully understand her remarks.
She must not permit any wrong "idea" to
enter her head - A person who always act
truly conscientious should feel easy as regard the
result of such actions and expect no unfavorable
change in friends whose friendship is worth re-
turning - Therefore confidence need not be misplaced

satisfaction - I know of no wish expressed be-
fore my coming up that she would be likely to

Scene after a Summer Shower
By A. Norton
The rain is o'ver - Have sense and bright
you pearly clouds reposing lie!
Cloud above cloud, a glorious sight,
Contrasting with the dark blue sky!
In grateful silence earth receives
The general blessing; fresh and fair,
Each flower expands its little leaves,
So glad the common joy to share.
The softened sunbeams, pour around
A fairy light, uncertain, pale;
The wind blows cool; the scented ground 
Is breathing odors on the gale.
[Mid?] you rich clouds' voluptuous pile,
Methinks some spirit of the air,

Might rest to gaze a while
Then turn to bathe and revel there.
The sun breaks forth - from off the scene
Tis floating veil of mist is flung;
And all the wilderness of green
With trembling drops of light is hung.
Now gaze on Nature - yet the same, -
Glowing with life, by [bruzes?] fanned,
Luxurious, lovely, as she came
Fresh in her youth from God's own hand
Hear the rich music of that voice,
Which sounds from all below, above;
She calls her children to rejoice
And round them throws her arms of love
Drink in her influence - [love?] [low?] born care,
And all the train of mean desire,
Refuse to breathe this holy air
And mid this living light expire.

Warwick Dec 3rd 1858
Dear Br Kendall
Your letter
dated 24th with enclosed favor of
same date, was received last Evening -
I have to say, in answer, that
I have decided to visit you this winter.
Providence permitting, I shall reach
La Porte in a few days after the receipt
of this letter, and will make every exer-
tion in my power to see you at
your home at the earliest date possible.
I shall try and avoid all unnecessary
preparation, which might cause a delay
in order to acquiesce with requirements
mentioned in your note; Yet to suddenly 
make my departure, to go so far, without
a little "fixing up" cannot be expected.
I shall expect but little more than
a welcome - To see you, sister, and little Edgar
smile and to know that your home is glad-
dened by my presence, even for a little while
will pay me for the trip, Whatever benefit that
[written on the left-hand side of the page]
result otherwise by reason of seeking your home at this time, I will be content
to hope for at present and let time & circumstances further decide - I will
merely say that I shall feel very grateful for an opportunity to be employed.
Please accept my heartfelt thanks for your kindness thus far, & for
your good intentions in regard to the future. Hoping soon to see you
& yours in good health and with smiling faces I now say adieu 
With love
Charles Reed

P.S. You may expect to hear from
me again before I reach your place as
I cannot start so as to reach LaPorte before the
last of the next week or middle of the week after.
I would however start tomorrow morning
if I could (or rather Monday next) - Mother says
it will take a few days to put me in travelling
order - I have had a severe cold but am getting better
in haste, Charles

La POrte Nov 30th 1862
Dear Sister Abby
Tis Sunday Eve
I am now writing in the store
and tis past 9 o'clock - I have
been thinking of you and
other friends and I cannot
retire without saying a few words.
I have been to church twice today
once in the PM & this eve -
Mrs Axtel was Baptized at the
Episcopal Church this PM. I went
there for the first time -I went to
Mr. Nayes Church this Eve - He was
present but a man from Minnesota
preached the Sermon & it was rather dull.
I sometimes go to hear Mr. [Seard?] but
have not attended church so regularly
as I did a year or so ago. I have 
no regular seat but if I am well
I shall try and secure one -

my health is rather better
than when I last wrote -
I have not so much of a 
cough although not entirely
free from a cough - I hope I
shall escape a severe cold &
cough this winter -
How Abby how do you
all do down to the farm. I be-
lieve you call it your Prairie Home
Are you all well - Is Mr. Kendall
gaining strength & improving as
he hoped to by going down there -
I heard that he was getting along
comfortably well and was better than
When here - I inquire often of
David but I get no news of
late - I get no letters and hear
nothing - I want to hear from you 
all right away - Please write this week
soon as you get this - Is Mary with
you yet and is she well - David
said a man told him she went

to Chicago - Said something about
her seeing about a school. He
said also something about her
seeing [Liverman?] - When I was
in Chicago a week or two ago I went
to his office to inquire but the
office was locked and as I had but
little time and knew not where
else to go I came back wondering
if she was really there - Want you
tell me all about it - And if
Mary is with you please tell her 
to write soon as possible for I
feel anxious to know what you
are all doing - If she has left
your place and gone to Chicago
or gone home East I would like
to know where she is I hope she
will not go East without seeing 
me before she goes - How are the boys
Edgar & Winnie - I thought when
you left here I should make you a
call before this but I have been alone

have not been any where
except once to Chicago -
There was an excursion train
25 car loads & rather crowded too
We got there about 11 A.M. left there
at 5 PM - Every body went almost
I invited the Misses W___
They said they had a pleasant time
We tho't perhaps we might find Mary
there from what David told me-
I wish I had found her there -
This is the only time I have been
anywhere & the first time I had
met Miss W- since you went away
I don't hear from Home lately -
I suppose tis because I don't write more
I must try and get in the way
of writing again - I don't intend
to neglect this duty but time gets
away somehow and I hardly know
how I could allow myself to be
so negligent about writing -
Thanksgiving went of rather dull
was alone mostly [illegible] Write soon
good bye love to all
Your Br.
Charles

Dear Sister Abby

Mr Hamilton is here and

Your last good
letter is yet unanswered. I
will try and delay no longer -
I was very glad to hear from you,
We shall not soon forget that
we ought to have seen each other
& had a good visit but having
no joy at greeting we had no
grief in parting - Nevertheless,
I had grief and regret that
it all happened as it did and
feel I have lost much pleasure
But I was in such a poor state
of health I could not have been
very cheerful - Still it would
have been so nice to have seen
you even for a day - I will hope
to see you before winter if well enough.

I will appreciate and hold 
in remembrance, the efforts, & 
Endeavors to make Our stay a 
pleasant one, in case we had 
Stopped at Your house – So you 
need not set it down as lost –

Warwick Oct 4th 1857
Dear Sister Abby
Many thanks to you, dear
Abby for your kind letter; I would long ago have
answered it had it been possible, but your little
namesake has engrossed my time and thoughts
I suppose Mary had written you that she has been
sick (!) for a while I was much afraid that her
life was to be, indeed, short, but am happy to
say that at present she seems to be doing well.
She is four months old today and weighs 14 3/4 lbs.
She has so far been a very troublesome child - never
one more so - though some what improved of late
You can well imagine that I have had enough to 
do - even more than my strength was equal to, sometimes
and but for the kindness of Friends, "one and all," don't
know how I could get along. Aunt Tamas has

lately returned from Northfield after a stay of five
weeks, and I find it makes a great difference in
my work. She does not try to work only to knit and
sometimes I have to fix it three and four times in an
hour. She has said nothing, but I presume she in-
tends to spend the winter with us. I shall dread the
winter, with a little babe in our cold room.
And now about Abbie's middle name - What shall it be?
My first thought was to have it Zibiah, then I thought I
would name her for my mother and as Abby Hannah
did not sound well call her Abby Leland. Your
folks all want her to have a name commencing with
J. if so I think we will have it Jennette. We have
thought too of calling her Abby Kendall; the truth is
we have thought of so many names and there are
so many to please, it is difficult deciding. She has
had a number of names given her. Elisa, Henry's wife 
wanted us to call her Annie Leland, cousin Angelina Bar-
ber "Emma Jennette," Louisa Jones - "Abby Louisa" - Mary
Davis - "Lottie Iola," &c and so on. So much for the name
Now perhaps you would like to know something of

her attainments - Well, in the first place, she can cry as
hard, as fast and as loud as any child I ever saw. And
of late she laughs as prettily; she even laughs "out loud" 
giggles and crows considerably. She knows her mother and
will not be easy if away from her one half hour, day or
night. I never have left her even for that time.
Allie is well and is none the less our pet and
pride than before the advent of her 'little sister.'
Samuel had been to church today says the
folks "at home" are all well. Chandler is going to
Boston and vicinity this week. By the way
what do you think of having a new sister?
What changed, time brings to us all!
Samuel Western Fever has not all "evaporated" nor
even abated but raged higher than ever. Pehaps
you know that he has offered his farm to John
Stearns for sixteen hundred dollars. The want
of means alone, prevents his taking it. He is com-
ing down soon to see about it. If we should
sell this place thinking to go west, I should
feel very badly. It seems to me now that 
well that I should be miserable.
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
She also knows her name.

I hardly think I would wish to sell but for
the present hard times. You probably no nothing
about it excepting what you hear; but I assure you,
we feel it sensibly.
Brother Henry and wife commenced teaching three
weeks tomorrow. His is the same school he had
last year, hers a little girls school in the same
building. She writes that she had not been home sick
yet. Brother Harding is in Houghton's stores in Athol
Albert is at home. Uncle Stillman's folks have
lately buried their youngest child a little boy of
about two years. Uncle David told S. today that
Mr. Putnam's folks have had word that Irene is very sick
with Typhoid Fever is not expected to recover. They must
feel very anxious about her. Mr. Pulnams little boy
too, I believe their youngest is very sick with Dysentery. 
Sarah Johnson has been at home several weeks - she
is going into [Milliner's?] shop in Athol next week. Report
says Dwight Fuller is very attentive to her.
She is coming to make me a visit this week. 
Cousins Martha and Annah Gale from [Medway?] are
in town; will visit us next week.

Monday Eve. I have been washing today and
am not a little tired; but as my husband is gone 
to Town and my children are sweetly sleeping I
will write a word more to you. I have just been
looking over what I wrote last eve and find that
it is hardly legible is badly composed and very
imperfect in every particular but when I tell
you that it was mostly written by candle light &
with a baby in my arms you will overlook &
excuse. I have vainly endeavored to persuade Samuel
to write a word & he is "fixed immovable."
I suppose you have heard of Mr. Ball's death? It seems
sad that he should be obliged to lease his childhood
home to die among comparative strangers. He was
brought to Warwick to be buried. Malinette's health
is much improved since they went to D. [Helber?]
remains much the same. Wallace has been [anry?]
pedling [Melodion's?] since he finished haying, excepting
an occasional visit home of a day or two. His wife
stays there alone with the boy they took from Deerfield
15 years old.

They do not intend to remain here, the coming winter
He thinks perhaps he may teach dancing school
again
I suppose Mary keeps you well posted in
the news &c so I will not spin my yarn much
longer this time. Samuel has just returned - Mary
sent word that perhaps she would write a note
to go with this letter. I hope you will oblige
me by writing soon, very soon. Albie talks a great
deal about "Aunt Abby," thinks she shall "go and
see her some day. Samuel sends his love to you
and Mr. Kendall. You will please present my
regards to him also, but don't let him see this
letter. Good night. Affectionately your sister
Maria H Reed
[Mrs. Samuel]

Warick Feb. 23rd 1873
Sunday Evening
Dear Sister Abby -
I have been feeling
guilty this long time for so neglecting you -
but the truth is first one thing after another
has continually prevented me, but I will
not weary you with a recital of all these
numerous hindrances. Sometimes, I have
been feeling disheartened and discouraged because
of Samuel's poor health and congruent perplex-
ing circumstances and beside I did not wish
to write you when he was so poorly, thinking
he would soon be better & ought not give you
needless anxiety. In the autumn, Nov. &
December, he was really miserable, a severe
cold and cough, something quite like the "Horse
disease" - was not confined to the house
but a few days, but was not able to do

his Barn chores for about two weeks and
for two or three months nothing more. But
now for the past six or eight weeks he has
been very well indeed better than for a year -
has been cutting some saplings from the lot he
lately purchased, which formerly belonged to Aunt
Reed. I hope he may continue to be well -
but don't know. Suck sicknesses as he had,
last spring, are so fearful in their consequences,
especially if of frequent occurrence. 
The rest of us have been usually well, though
Alma & myself have both had the Rush within a
few weeks, which made us quite sick, but for
a few days only. And Annie has been more
unwell than usual this winter, not able to
attend school for several weeks, but better
now. The fact is in a family of five or six, some
one of the number is usually ailing. But on
the whole, we have little severe sickness, seldom
employ a Physician.
Alma attended school this winter, for although
I needed her very much at home, I felt that

as we could probably never give her any other
chance, for schooling. I ought not require her
to stay at home a single day. We board
the Teacher a Miss Packard from Dorchester &
are having a long time (sixteen weeks) & a good
school. It has four weeks longer to [Reep?].
So much for ourselves - and now, how are you
and your little boys? Is Eddie I suppose
would resent being called a little boy, as 
he, no doubt, feels himself to be almost a
man and a great help to you in many
ways. I often think of you & wish we could 
know, more particularly, how you are situated.
I know you must have a great deal of
care, if not hard work, but hope your
health and strength will be equal to your
needs. We have not seen or heard directly
from Chandler since he went west. Cannot
conceive why he never comes to Warwick
I suppose you hear from Emily? She is
having remarkable opportunity for enjoyment
and culture and rest from work & care.

Mrs. Draper received a long and very interest-
ing letter from her recently, which I had the
pleasure of reading. She seems to be [illegible] pleas-
antly situated, which Jamie & her husband and
Mary & I concluded they do not propose to
return to Eng. till May. I am afraid will
be a long time before we see her again. Sam
is the only one of his family or name now
in town, and be sometimes quite alone.
My Father, too, is getting to be in years &
cannot have a "long lease of life." He calls him-
self well, but he looks far from it and from
the fact, that they are talking of selling their
Farm. I know he feels so ['Miner'?] the youngest
of the family is the only child, at home. She is
seventeen. And Alma, do you know, is al-
most eighteen years old! Does it seem possible
And we have been married nearly 20 
years! Where have the years flown? And
what has been their record?
Grandpa Child still lives, is almost 96 
years old and still active, bodily & mentally.

What a cold winter we are having!
Today the mercury is eight degrees above zero
but as 'tis windy and rough it seems much colder.
Friday, we had a severe [illegible] storm to yesterday
& today it has blown and drifted, so all the roads
are full. There has been very little stirring today -
No meeting at our Church. We have a new
minister a Mr. Heston from Barnstable, he boards
this winter but will move his family (wife &
one daughter) here in the spring.
We are to have a Fair here the 6th of March
for he benefit of our society.
We have very pleasant neighbors in the other
part of our house - the Baptist minister here
they have been here two years & will remain
another. They are elderly people, have an
only child a daughter, who was married
here about a month ago. I would like to 
give you an account of the wedding and the
wedding presents but my space will not per
mit. They have many wealthy relatives &
friends and she married into a family of

means, so she had numerous and elegant
presents, of course. We were the only persons
invited to the Reception & dinner and all in
Town. The ceremony was performed in Church.
We have been much attached to this family
& should regret to have them leave.
We have just heard of my Uncle (Dr.) Gales'
death. He has long been a great sufferer but
at least he is released. His remains are
to be brought to Warwick for interment on
Tues. of this week. I suppose he will be taken here to our house, and the friends
here & in Winchester will gather here to take
the last look. Uncle Rich is still living but
Aunt Alma, you know passed on more than 
a year ago. And last Sept. Uncle Stockwell
died. So one after another of our friends depart.
Aunt Reed is spending the winter with
Melinda & is quite comfortable, though never as
well since her severe sickness in the summer
and autumn. Mr. Golds boy's people are much
as usual, they have a little son of [James?] with

a little boy [illegible] five & six years old. Ann
Maria, went out to Davenport in the Autumn & took
him home with her. Mr. Goldsburg was 76 years old
a few days since & Mr. John Goldsburg is 78 and
still vigorous and active. He is chairman of the
school Comm. & enjoys it hugely. Still he is most too
old a man for the position. His wife's daughter
Lucy married Geo. [Proetir?] & went to Nebraska
a few years since and they now have two chil-
dren. The last a boy as they have just heard,
named John Goldsburg. This pleases Mr. J. very
much & he proposed to give him a gold watch
which his grandfather Goldsburg gave him
the day he was born, that is, as he says,
if he is a "good looking fellow."
Ann Mayo is spending the winter with
her sisters at Glens Falls, N.Y.

Samuel and the children send love to you
and your children. Accept with the love of
yr. sister Maria H. Reed

West but Aunt's family and they go

seated at the breakfast table I found
the table covered with white linen Damask
table cloths, and laid with white crockery,
white handled Revives silver fork, little sep-
arate individual salt [sells?], and a silver
coaster, not so large as yours. I was helped
to steak mashed potatoes, hash, bread & butter,
coffee, which I accepted Sunday morning of course
but her heat-griddle cakes, and doughnuts.
So if that is a sample of the fare one
needn't waste away for want  of food.
After breakfast Im seated by the south
window "seeing what I can see." One white
horse two little wood colored shanties. Two
broad clitches of water each side of the road
in one of which 7 or eight white storks
are swimming. Several long piles, piles
of nice looking railroad wood, which
I'm thinking would do you so much
good if it was at your house, four
frail ways and an engine house, six or seven
telegraph wires, farther back ([almond?] lake,

My Dear Sis
I have just returned from an 
excursion to the summit of Mt. Holyoke. And although 
I am almost exhausted, I propose to narrate to you 
an account of the splendid time I have had.
We took breakfast this morning at 5 1/2 o'clock. 
I rose at 4 o'clock and did an hours domestic 
work before breakfast. And at 6 1/2 the coaches 
came from Springfield to take is to Hokanomb [Hockanum], 
a village near the base of the mountain. There was 
over one hundred in both companies, one went 
at 6 1/2 and the other at 8 o'clock. I went in 
the Second Co. When the coaches came back from 
carrying the first co. we all ran down and had 
our names crossed and then out to the coaches. 
The stage coach came first and I mounted the 
top with 5 others & 9 inside. Next came the Champion 
with 4 noble steeds carrying 18. Then 2 Omnibuses 
with 12 each and a large covered coach behind with 
9 or 10 passengers. We started off singing, "In early day 
away, away. To the fields and woods away". While the 
ladies that remained at home either in groups 
in the gardens or from the piazzas and windows 
waved their handkerchiefs singing "Goodbye, Goodbye." "
"That good old word Good-bye." Oh! it was perfectly splendid

We arrived at Hokanum & paid our Quarter, and started 
for the mountain. Mr. Hawkes and two of the teachers 
went with us as guides. Our way led us through mire 
bogs, thickets groves glens, up steep rocky places almost per-
pendicular, and ever and anon we would lose our foothold 
and fall back. On we toiled one behind another. 
Like Hannibal crossing the Alps till at length we 
reached the spring; stopped and refreshed ourselves 
with the cooling draught and proceeded. So steep 
and winding was the way that we could not see those 
four feet below us. We reached the summit at 
11 o'clock devoured the cakes we had brought with us and 
then began to gaze about. Just on the summit is a hotel 
( a cabin like) where refreshments were kept for visiters.
But us purchasing anything but water which was 
three pennies a glass had been strictly forbidden we 
did not give them much custom.  They had two 
telescopic glasses so that all might have an opportunity 
to take a view. I saw 4 of the United States beside this 
N.H. VT Conn. & NY., eight or 9 villages Northampton, East 
Hampton, Old Hadley, So. Hadley, Deerfield, Amherst, Holyoke 
City, & Springfield. The Armory in Springfield City was 
distinctly visible - also eat & west rock New Haven, Catskill 
Mts. N.Y. also Saddle Mountain, Camelsback Vt & Monadnock 
N.H. I wish you had been on the summit and swung 
your handkerchief. The beautiful valley of the Connecticut 
lay stretched out before us in all its varied beauty. 
While the course of the winding could be seen till

till it entered the St. Connecticutt. Oh how beautiful! 
how perfectly splendid it was as it wound along 
830 feet below us. An island was in the river just 
in the shape of a coffin called Titans coffin. It con-
tained 21 acres of Land hedged all round with trees. 
And at a short distance below another containing 
84 acres this was inhabited. Several rafts were floating down 
like tiny specks. After gazing as long as we wished we 
went down to the grove, there we sung and some of 
the old scholars and a few of the news ones practised 
calisthenics. It was beautiful to see them. I wish you 
could have been there. We then went to the place 
where a hammock was placed and after we had all 
been rocked out went back to the Hotel where we Regis-
tered our names in a Book kept for the purpose; 
and the walls of the building within and without 
were filled with names carved and written upon 
them. We started to come down at 2 o'clock; and 
found our way more tedious than going up. We came 
round by Titans Piazza a huge rocky mass, elevated at 
an immense distance above us. Three rows of 
hexagonal cones extended over the whole impending 
over our heads. Just beneath these was a huge 
aperture in the rock called Titans Chasm. I perfectly 
struck with admiration at this sight. Minute pieces 
of this rock shelving off from the other formed a steep 
hill over which we climbed. We then descended 
the mountain and found the coaches in waiting

for us. And we glad to seat ourselves again we leaped 
into the carriages in about an hour were Landed 
at the Seminary. Tired weary and hungry we sought

wanted I should come up and tell her all about 
it as she did not go. Said she had the shawl 
nicely spread on the bed for me. The temptation 
was so strong I could not resist so I went .- And stayed 
till supper bell rang. But when I got down to the

over my plate. Sarah & Amelia are extremely 
tired, we have all independently got our 
shawls and gone to bed. Now hence I am writing

how you like? if as well as you expected &c &c I suppose

visit here during your vacation. I think you would 
enjoy it - much and I should jump for joy off my 
Hind-feet. By the way I possess but one. Have 
you purchased any new apparrel yet - And what is it? 
I have purchased anything yet - Don't know wheth-
er I shall or not. Write what you have got. Will you. 
I have changed my room and roommates since 
I returned. I room now in the 2nd story front-side 
with Miss Amelia Wilde of Newark of N.J. & Miss

and stayed over a week with her babe. While
her husband went to Boston and Portland for goods.
He is a merchant in Rutland now. We renewed
our Institute days I tell you. I have the room
that John Goldsburg had, he boarded here when
he taught the Academy, so it seems like home
you know. I only want you here. Why is it, I don't
know why we are so separated. I have mourned about
it ever since I have been here, till one morning
this week I got up and was thinking it all ever
sad, and wondering why it was so, and something
seemed to tell me, "It isn't best now". Ever since
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Give a deal of love to dear Charles my dear brother, tell him to write me dear good.
letters very often - I hope he will be careful of his health, you must see to it Abby -
I hope you will both have an excellent time and you must both keep me informed
of every passing event - I shall long for your letters

that, I have felt willing to give it up -
It is funny is'nt it, something like your font pedal
impression. I think that was real funny.
No, I have not heard from the west. When you
hear, you must tell me all the news. I am
glad you didn't send our Daguerrotypes for I don't
think they are very good ones, mine especially
people here don't think it is. They say it
don't look so well as the Original - that's by way
of compliment I suppose. No, I have not seen
Velvet Eyes! Dear, oh dear! I know not where he's gone!
and my poor heart too! And 'tis such a pity,
for Mr. Ruggles is Town Clerk, and he says if
I will be married up here, I shall have a certifi-
cate free, and Mrs. Ruggles says I shall have
a nice bridal veil. Now isn't it too bad, and
Candidate gone too. So it is all vanity and vexation
& spirit to think of it. There was a wedding in
church last Thursday, one the week before, and
two more this month. Tell cousin Marie Dr.
Blake is to be married this month to Miss Mar-
garet Harrington. I have seen Mr Jackson's
family several times, all well. I delivered
your message, Harriette sends her love in
return. I guess you can send some trimming.
for my dress in a newspaper - I want you should if you
can so we can have them alike. When you write tell me how
you have got yours made how your bonnet is trimmed out
side and inside. I guess I shall get me a straw hat to wear
to school. Write soon and tell me everything - I have just got
Hiawatha and tomorrow I shall read from it in memory of Dear Boston
Give my love to all our friends write soon to your dear sister Mary

[copied?]
Walpole May 24th 1856
Saturday Morning
My dear sister Abby:
I wanted to write you
to day, because it is your birth-day. What are you
going to do to-day to celebrate it? O! don't I wish
you was here, or rather I was there? I guess so.
Dear me! I long for the days when we at home
shall narrate summer adventures. Or games rather
for I don't have any. Time passes. We have
now finished seven weeks. Sometimes it seems
more and some times less. You wished to know the
exact time when I should go home. I can't
tell the very day yet, but I expect about
the 1st of July. Perhaps the last week in
June. I have not calculated exactly, for
I don't know exactly how long our term is.
Probably 12 weeks. I shall probably write you again
but if I don't, you may expect I shall
be at home the 1st of July. I hope you will
get through your visit by that time, for I shall 
want you at home when I go. I don't know
whether I shall return or not. I have not
said or thought any thing about it since 
I came. Probably shant before the term is through.

At any rate it seems as if I shall die if
I have to teach much longer. I am begin-
ning to feel dreadful tired now. Yesterday and
day before I was almost sick. Dear! you don't know
how much I have to endure. Yes you do. But
some don't. I am glad Abby you have taken
this summer to rest. You need it. I hope you
are enjoying your visit and that it will
do you good.
I received your good letter, that I had been
longing for, more than a week, last Wednesday. Also
the paper and its contents all safe. I'm glad
you sent it. I had just got ready to put it on.
I like it much. I think it looks very rich on.
I have put it on to the capes already. I did
think I should finish my dress today. But I Guess
I shan't quite. If you are about having yours
cut I will tell you about mine. The whole we
got I found a scant pattern, so that I had 
to get some very light blue, to face the sleeves
and capes. I have 7 and 3/4 breadths in my
skirt. We took of a little to piece out the front
the silk was so narrow. If I had through I 
should have been so short I might have
saved a little more by not making the skirt
quite so long. I have had my lace straw
bonnet dressed over and put on my

white ribbon. I got some lace for the inside
and some straw for the cape they set it under
here on the lining but my cape was made
so I did not alter it and put it right on
the edge. It looks about the same. I have
put a bow of white ribbon that I got for
strings like yours, I never used it so now
I have put it in the inside with the
lace I have not put in any flowers. I don't
know whether I shall or not. I guess not though.
I have bought a straw hat to wear to school.
It is Leghorn cost a dollar. I have trimmed
it with that green and brown ribbon you know
that I got some time ago. I presume
you can get one there if you want too.
I thought I would, seeing I had not much
of anything else to wear to school.
I haven't heard from home yet. I don't know
what it means. I have written twice. No
I have not heard from the west either. I am
afraid something has happened to them. As for
Velvet Eyes, I'm afraid he is not exactly the
Velvet Eyes I first thought he was. I have also
discovered that my heart instead of being lost,
only received a heavy shock, and I think it
may recover in time. I am surprised at
your suspicions of that other Gentleman!

I don't think he would do a wicked
deed no more than Dear Candidate would
Beside, I have heard from my youth
up and so have you I guess, that
"Homely people are always good". So I think
you can relieve your mind of its anxiety, for
your suspicions I think are entirely groundless
this time. I am astonished at L.F. hiding
up so. I don't believe he's had that maple
sugar. If I was there I would call and
see. I'm glad Charlie's health improves. Give
my love to him and tell him I've been
expecting to hear from him a long long time
I wrote my first letter home to him, but
I don't know as he got it. Tomorrow
you are to have such a treat going to hear
F.D. Huntington. Oh! how I should like
to hear him I shall certainly think of you
tomorrow. Walpole is looking her best now.
'Tis really quite a beautiful place, some very
beautiful gardens. Miss Howe my associate
teacher is boarding with me now. Her friends
have gone to visit and she stops here while
they are absent. I send you the stamps
I don't know as you will find them con-
venient, but perhaps they will answer for
change in case of emergency.
give my love to all
friends that inquire for me
and write me soon again
good bye, from your
affectionate Mary sister

Walpole N.H.
Oct 20, 1856
Monday evening
Dear sister,
How do you do?
I thought I would run home and
stay a little while this evening for
I have been thinking of what you
told me so much to day that I could
not wait any longer.
I was a little surprised - and
yet 'twas no more than I expected
But somehow I never have looked
upon such a result as real - although
I know we have so often talked about
it. It has always seemed like a 
gleam of sunshine (that visit four years
ago) and 'twas a circumstance that
has furnished us many a long and pleas-
and talk-over, surmising and wondering
what 'twas for, and how it would end.
And there I have general dismissed 
the thought. And to-day the possibility
of its reality stares me in the face.
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Mother don't you tell Abby get married and not let me know.
I shall always be "your baby" - Shan't I so there - Abby's story
turned my thoughts [tother-side-noxibus?] - good bye -

I know not what to say or what to
advise, other than to follow the true
promptings of your heart, and trust to
God for the result. That you have
loved him well I have no doubt Abby.
Is he all you wish? Is he the one for
whom you could leave all? Home, mother
Chandler, Emily, Charles, Samuel, Mary, will
his love his companionship fill the place
of all these your dearest earthly ties? If so
if God wills, be his. And may it be a happy
union. But the thought of it has
brought many tears. Although I believe
him to be good, pure, and for ought
I know worthy in every respect, the thought
of giving your love and best affections
really to another brings a sadness I can
not drive away! Once married, and thick
and fast will new objects crowd in to 
separate the strong link of sisterly love.
I know it is right. I know it is the way
of the world. But it makes me feel sad
to think of it to-day. It makes me want
to come right home, and stay, and talk
about it. It seems as if I couldn't stay
here now. I've lived along thinking

perhaps you would be here with me
bye and bye, and now it is improbable.
Do you remember what I told you that
a spirit voice seemed to whisper to me.
"It isn't best, Mary"? Well perhaps it is'nt.
I'm sure I can't read the future.
You must keep me advised in all the
matters so that I may be prepared for
any result. I'm glad I'm coming home
so soon. Don't know when though. Can't be 
a great while long. But you must be
sure to send me all important news.
I hope your sun will light and cheer
you all the way through life. But I 
don't know but I shall have to go my
journey all alone in the dark. For I 
believe my sun hasn't 'ris' yet. If it
has its behind a dark cloud I guess.
I want very much to see the 'Daguerrotype'
You ask if you did right to send ours. I don't
know why it was wrong, only mine no business
to have gone. You meant think of my
ever taking a nap now. For I don't feel
a bit like any way. Your story will keep
me wide awake till I get home I assure
you. What does mother say now about the west

I will send the ribbon in a paper by the same mail have no use
for it at present. You can keep it separate
or mark it so we can know which is which
but I don't know whether I shall ever want
it again or not. I didn't get new ribbon -
I put on that that I got at Forbes you
know. It came very handy. I have to be
rather careful of the pennies myself. For
fear I shan't make the ends meet.
Miss Stowe and I reported six boys 
apiece to-day. Trials will keep coming -
Harriette Jackson came to see me Sat-
staid a long time had a good chat. She 
is intending to visit Bangor next month
Rev. Mr Lothrap is to be installed in the
unitarian church next week Wednesday.
Mr. White recently from Kansas lectures here
next Friday. Do you know when Thanks-
giving is in Massachusetts? I hope it will
be the same time 'tis here. Charles
wrote me he thought he should be home
then and perhaps spend the winter.
I shall be impatient to see you and
here further news from the west. Of any
plans and so forth. But I must hurry back
now I've staid so long. Come to see me soon
good-night here's a kiss and good-bye,
sis Mary -
